In addition, there is evidence that the area under the plasma concentration versus time curves in rats and humans correlates reasonably well when doses are normalized to mg/m2 (Contrera et al. 1995). We conclude that the approach of converting NOAEL doses to an HED based on body surface area correction factors (i.e., b = 0.67) should be maintained for selecting starting doses for initial studies in healthy volunteers since: (1) mg/m2 normalization is widely used throughout the toxicology and pharmacokinetic research communities; (2) mg/m2 normalization provides a more conservative conversion; (3) there are no data to suggest a superior method for converting NOAELs; and (4) CDER has significant experience in establishing safe starting doses based on mg/m2, and it is readily calculated.
